Actually, we can see in 3D with only one eye.  This is because our eyes are round in shape.  The angle of the incoming light can be measured by where it hits our retina.  This gives us information which is not available when looking at a television screen.  The light from each pixel simply goes out in all directions equally and does not contain the kind of angular information that we receive when looking at a three dimensional object.  Stereoscopic vision provides us with additional information and improves our ability to judge distances, but it isn't the sole or even primary source of information for 3D vision.  When looking at the objects on my desk with only one eye, I can clearly see that they are not 2D, and I can also judge distances.  Just not as well as when using both eyes.  If the pixels on a television screen could alter the intensity of the light they produce depending on the angle it is emitted at, the image would look 3D without the need for silly glasses.  Actually, it would look more realistically 3D than methods using stereoscopic approaches.

THANK YOU for pointing out that what everyone keeps calling 'holograms' aren't actually holograms.

They're actually Pepper's Ghost images made by projecting a normal 2D image onto a reflective, transparent plate (a window for example) that's tilted at an angle towards the viewer. It creates a kind of motion parallax that tricks your brain into thinking it's a 3D image when it's not.

I was born with a very lazy eye, which was mostly surgically corrected when I was very young. For the past decade, pretty much since the 3D fad started, I've been aware that I don't see the world the same as everyone else. I can't say it impacts me much, though I do wonder what I miss.

The first time I was at a 3D movie and the effect started working at a rather extreme moment, I nearly panicked. I started waving my hands around to swat at the objects moving around my face. It was a startling and shocking moment in my life. That was about 8 years ago.

Since then, I have been to dozens of 3D movies, and for the most part I don't get anything from it; but every now and then it works. I honestly don't feel like the world is flat to me, but I will admit that watching a movie doesn't look much different from watching the world go by to me either.

I still can't see 3D even though I've been to movies in 3D they did not fix my sight. I can still only focus out of one eye at a time, now I wonder what I'm missing out on since she said I'd only see the world in 2D. I guess I will never know.

Another problem with 3D films, apart from the motion parallax, has to do with depth of field. In "real life" you see pretty much everything in focus, or at least you can switch the focus instantaneously between the background and the foreground. In movies, you have a 3D image but the background is often out of focus. And you can't focus on it. It's kind of weird and uncomfortable.

The problem of having to sit still and look straight at the screen to see glassesless 3D has been solved (somewhat) by face tracking cameras. They track your movement and adjust the 3D image accordingly so you can see it from different angles. Nintendo has integrated this technology into their New 3DS. It still doesn't include parallax or the ability to physically move and look around objects though.

2:00 Those are not the only depth perception cues. There is also depth of field. Since your eyes can only focus on a certain range of distance, everything else is out of focus, so that's a cue to distance. It's one of the main reasons "3D" movies are so confusing to the brain for a lot of people. Your eyes are focused at infinity, where anything less than around 4 meters should be out of focus. But things at 3 meters ARE in focus because they're not really at 3 meters.

You left-out focal parallax—the simplest (mon)ocular depth-focus...
You left-out focal color parallax—which is more an oddity, but real...
And, ignored the head-tilting binocular-vertical-alignment problem...
(which is both a DoP-certification and audience-nuisance problem).
Plus, there are several other 3D-projection technologies, to discuss.

There's one more form of direct depth perception that this video doesn't mention - and that's focal depth - as you switch attention between foreground and background objects, the one you're not looking at goes out of focus. It's limited - anything more than a meter or two away is at pretty much the same focus - but it's something you can see with just one eye without moving your head.

Holograms are only a subset of the class of devices known as volumetric displays, and there are potential technologies in this field (like swept-volume displays) that I'd argue are even more promising than holograms.

Correctly programmed virtual reality headsets - such as the Oculus Rift should also count as true 3D, because there are two different screens in the glasses, one for each eye, as well as motion tracking, which can then adjust the display give the impression of motion parallax. (if well programmed.)

Which is great for game, but could as lead to true 3D, and 360 degree, movies. Imagine actually looking around a battlefield, or hearing noise behind you and not having to wait until it comes on screen but being able to turn around and see what it is!

I feel like even if films were 3D we'd still be missing a key part of the experience by just sitting in a movie theater and watching it. I like the aspect of being able to move around the film like you showed us in the hologram museum. Maybe an experience rather than a show like say a haunted house or something would be better.

Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality headsets can also give 'true' 3D. Binocular parallax achieved by giving each eye a specific image. Motion parallax achieved through head tracking.

Unless holograms do, none of the examples you gave (or even VR) include one of the most important ways we judge distance: focus. The blurring caused by our lenses when focusing on different depths of field helps us to differentiate between foreground and background. Having two flat images sent to our eyes from the same distance means we only ever use one focal point.

Even HMDs with rotation and translation tracking can't do real 3D.  You'd need something like virtual retinal displays with focal accommodation using dynamic beam focus for each eye as it scans the image onto each retina.  This is also the reason why shutter glasses, polarized glasses, and HMDs now are so fatiguing, even if you don't take into account head tracking lag and other issues.

It's just basic two-dimensional trigonometry...there's nothing truly three-dimensional about Cartesian coordinate systems.

We don't have 3D vision we have 2.5D vision. If we had 3D vision we could see around occluded objects and around corners. Our depth perception is synthesized by inference by our brains. This is why optical illusions are common, it's trivial to fool the brain with false parallax data.

By the way there is not just the polarazing kind of 3D TV but also the shutter one, where the glasses synchronize with the TV. The TV flickers twice the speed of the movie showing the left and right image alternatingly and the glasses block one eye at a time. This way you can look at the screen from any angle but have the downside of having only half the brightness which would be possible. On the other hand you can implement this technology on almost any screen that supports at least 60 Hz. Also some people complain about headache when watching shutter 3D.

At my university we used to have a virtual reality cave. We're building it back up due to building renovations.

Our system uses a 100 Hz display, with glasses that have each glass open and close using LCD filters at 50 Hz.

We also have a little device connected to the glasses in order to provide head tracking. That way, we've been able to not only give the binocular parallax, but also the motion parallax. That makes our version of Minecraft (alpha) in the cave really awesome.

It doesn't really do anything for movies (unless they've been animated and allow for to be rendered in real time by 5 PC's and a bit if head tracking equipment at 100Hz ...) but for simulations it's pretty awesome. (Crime scenes, protein models and stuff like that for our Chemistry and Forensics labs).

Dianna I am a theoretical physicist (astrophysicist) myself, now semi-retired, and I worked mostly in the field of geometrodynamics (i.e., gravitation theory/general relativity) during my career.  From personal experience I can add an additional wrinkle on the topic of this excellent video.  When I was 16 years old I lost the sight completely in my left eye (due to an accident).  At first, as you point out, the world appeared "flat" to me.  However, over time, my brain compensated and I re-developed depth perception; not based on stereoscopy but, instead, based on experience and the known relative size of objects (the human brain is pretty amazing!).  I am now 65 years old and the world definitely does not look "flat" to me.  In fact, I played minor league professional baseball in the early 1970s for 3 years and did just fine (I was an outfielder).  The doctors told me that had I been much older when the accident occurred my brain may not have been able to compensate quite as well.  So, my youth at the time worked in my favor.  The main downside to having only one eye, as I see it, is that I am very well acquainted with the right-hand side of my nose.  Most people don't even see their noses unless they cross their eyes.  I see mine all of the time!  Have a wonderful day and keep making these wonderful videos.  We need to get young people excited about science again and what you are doing goes a very long way toward achieving that goal!

My biggest issue with 3d is that the cinematographers use depth of field. It's not natural to focus on something that appears blurry. Depth of field works really well at directing your focus for flat images, but when the image has depth I find myself looking at the out of focus stuff because my brain still thinks it's 'in focus'. I'm combining two images and getting depth information for imagery that has 'fake' depth information added to it already.

I know that red light is easier to work with, but the recreation of Leia should have been done with blue light.

As for video and color I had a thought: Persistence of vision.
If three different plates of color were holographically recorded at once and then the corresponding images were cycled quickly enough your brain could do the blending. Of course the required interference pattern for red, green and blue holographic plates would be different so either the plates themselves would have to move too or there would have to be some kind of digital holographic surface that could build the image discreetly, pixel by pixel. Of course if the pixels are already cycling to create a color image the next step to video isn't too crazy.
On the other hand creating a single pixel that can dynamically interfere with different colors of light tens of times a second is no easy feat.

Impressive video, as always, but why haven't you touched upon the amazing vr technologies like Oculus Rift? It offers both stereoscopic and motion parallax. Although, in contrast to the 3D movies which are 2 2D images, it requires a 3D environment projected into 2 separate 2D screens with optics

A bit more information on 3D technologies - there are videos online that allow you to see 3D with no glasses, but you have to be able to cross your eyes like the magic-eye pictures. If you can do it (it’s hard) it may end in a headache. Here’s a good example of one: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zBa-bCxsZDk. Also, the easy way to create 3D movies is to use two cameras. However many 3D movies are made 3D in post-production. The editors move the foreground in front of the background different amounts for the two images to create binocular parallax. The post-production will give some depth to the images, but will not be the true 3D you see when you look outside, unless they really went all-out in post production. The same is true of 2D to 3D conversions. There are some 3D TVs that can convert regular 2D images to 3D using the same technique. They use software that creates two images in real time, moving the foreground slightly to the left or right in front of the background in each image.

Hugo is actually one of the surprisingly rare 3D films actually shot with two cameras. Most are still shot with conventional 2D cameras, and then post-converted to 3D. And that's a process that still sends shivers down my spine when I think of the man-hours required to essentialy cut out people and objects, frame by frame, and distribute them through the Z axis and make sure the depth makes sense in motion, etc. And those can still feel a bit like cardboard cutouts moving around, compared to real stereoscopic footage.

Also, for those not familiar with it, you can google "cross-eyed 3D" for a simple hack to view stereoscopic 3D images without any special equipment (glasses or special displays). It takes a bit of practice, though.
